question:
The right to adopt another heir in place of one's son was re-established –

U.P. P.C.S. (Spl.) (Mains) 2004
option_1: Government of India Act of 1858
option_3: With the issuance of Sanad in 1860
option_4: The Empress's proclamation of 1858
solution:
• The right to adopt an heir was re-established with the Queen Victoria’s Proclamation issued on 1st November 1858.
  • This proclamation reversed the Doctrine of Lapse, which was used earlier by Lord Dalhousie to annex princely states that had no natural male heir.
  • The Empress’s Proclamation assured Indian princes that their traditional rights, titles, and privileges would be respected under British rule.
  • Specifically, it restored the native rulers' right to adopt a son and have him recognized as their legitimate successor.
  • This was part of broader efforts to gain the loyalty of Indian princely states after the 1857 revolt.

Additional Information:

  • The proclamation was read publicly by Lord Canning in Allahabad.
  • The policy shift aimed to stabilize India by respecting Indian customs and sovereignty of native rulers.

question:
Queen Victoria was appointed Empress of India by-

38th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 1992
solution:
• Queen Victoria was officially proclaimed Empress of India on 1st January 1877 during the Delhi Durbar.
  • The title was created under the Royal Titles Act of 1876, passed by the British Parliament.
  • The proclamation ceremony was conducted under the viceroyalty of Lord Lytton, the then Viceroy of India.
  • This move was aimed at strengthening British imperial authority and symbolizing the Crown’s dominance after the 1857 Revolt.
  • Though the Act was passed in 1876, the formal appointment and public declaration took place in 1877.

Additional Information:

  • The Delhi Durbar of 1877 was the first imperial assemblage in India.
  • Queen Victoria’s new title emphasized her direct sovereignty over the Indian Empire, marking the solidification of the British Raj.

question:
Which of the following Governor General abolished slavery in India?

U.P.U.D.A./L.D.A. (Mains) 2010

U.P. P.C.S. (Spl.) (Pre) 2008

U.P.P.C.S (Mains) 2011
solution:
• Slavery was officially abolished in India during the tenure of Lord Ellenborough through an act passed in 1843.
  • The Indian Slavery Act, 1843 declared slavery illegal and void in British India.
  • It prohibited sale, purchase, or ownership of any person as a slave under British rule.
  • This act was influenced by rising humanitarian concerns and the global abolition movement initiated earlier in Britain.
  • Lord Ellenborough served as the Governor-General of India from 1842 to 1844, and the act was one of the key reforms during his tenure.

Additional Information:

  • Prior to this, slavery existed in various forms across India, often unregulated under customary and religious practices.
  • The Act ensured that no legal claim could be made over any person as a slave in civil courts.

question:
Which one of the following pairs is correctly matched?

U.P. Lower Sub. (Pre) 1998
option_1: Lord Cornwallis – Permanent Settlement
option_2: Lord Wellesley – Intelligent inaction
option_3: Lord Dalhousie– Subsidiary Treaty
option_4: Lord Canning – Establishment of Indian National Congress
solution:
• Lord Cornwallis – Permanent Settlement: ✔️ Correct

    He introduced the Permanent Settlement of Bengal in 1793, which fixed land revenue with zamindars permanently.

  • Lord Wellesley – Intelligent inaction: ❌ Incorrect

    Wellesley followed an aggressive expansionist policy through the Subsidiary Alliance, not a policy of inaction.

  • Lord Dalhousie – Subsidiary Treaty: ❌ Incorrect

    The Subsidiary Alliance system was developed by Lord Wellesley, not Dalhousie. Dalhousie is known for the Doctrine of Lapse.

  • Lord Canning – Establishment of Indian National Congress: ❌ Incorrect

    Indian National Congress was founded in 1885, while Lord Canning’s tenure ended in 1862.

Additional Information:

  • Permanent Settlement aimed to ensure regular revenue but led to zamindari exploitation of peasants.
  • Lord Cornwallis also introduced the Cornwallis Code, reforming civil services and judiciary.

question:
Which of the following is not correctly matched?

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1998
option_1: Lord Cornwallis – Permanent Settlement
option_2: Lord Wellesley – Subsidiary Treaty
option_3: Lord Dalhousie – Doctrine of Lapse
option_4: Lord Canning – Supreme Inaction
solution:
• Lord Cornwallis – Permanent Settlement: ✔️ Correct

    He introduced the Permanent Settlement in 1793, fixing land revenue permanently with zamindars in Bengal.

  • Lord Wellesley – Subsidiary Treaty: ✔️ Correct

    Lord Wellesley developed and extensively used the Subsidiary Alliance system to expand British control over Indian princely states.

  • Lord Dalhousie – Doctrine of Lapse: ✔️ Correct

    He implemented the Doctrine of Lapse, annexing states that had no natural heir (e.g., Jhansi, Satara, Nagpur).

  • Lord Canning – Supreme Inaction: ❌ Incorrect

    The phrase "Supreme Inaction" is wrongly attributed to Lord Canning. He was known for post-1857 reconstruction, not inaction.

    The policy of "Masterly Inactivity" is more commonly associated with Lord Lawrence in relation to Afghan affairs.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Canning’s real contributions include:
    • Reading Queen Victoria’s Proclamation (1858)
    • Becoming the first Viceroy of India
    • Starting the Indian Penal Code (drafted earlier) and initiating post-revolt reforms

question:
During whose reign was the 'Permanent Settlement' introduced?

U.P. Lower Sub. (Pre) 2008
solution:
• The Permanent Settlement was introduced in 1793 during the tenure of Lord Cornwallis, who served as the Governor-General of Bengal from 1786 to 1793.
  • It was a land revenue system primarily implemented in Bengal, Bihar, and Orissa.
  • Under this system, the revenue was fixed permanently with the zamindars, who were made landowners and tasked with collecting taxes from peasants.
  • This policy aimed at ensuring stable revenue for the British but led to exploitation of peasants by zamindars.
  • Though the idea originated under Warren Hastings, it was formally implemented by Lord Cornwallis.

Additional Information:

  • The Permanent Settlement was a part of the broader Cornwallis Code.
  • The system later proved problematic due to non-revision of tax rates and zamindari oppression.

question:
Which of the following is not correctly matched?

U.P. U.D.A./L.D.A. (Pre) 2001
option_1: Lord Cornwallis – Permanent Settlement
option_2: Lord Wellesley – Subsidiary Treaty System
option_3: Lord Hastings – Second Anglo-Maratha War
option_4: Lord William Bentinck – Seventeenth Regulation of 1829
solution:
• (a) Lord Cornwallis – Permanent Settlement: ✔️ Correct

    Lord Cornwallis introduced the Permanent Settlement in 1793 to fix land revenue with zamindars.

  • (b) Lord Wellesley – Subsidiary Treaty System: ✔️ Correct

    Lord Wellesley established the Subsidiary Alliance System, through which Indian states accepted British protection in return for stationing British troops.

  • (c) Lord Hastings – Second Anglo-Maratha War: ❌ Incorrect

    The Second Anglo-Maratha War (1803–1805) took place during the rule of Lord Wellesley, not Lord Hastings.

    Lord Hastings was associated with the Third Anglo-Maratha War (1817–1818).

  • (d) Lord William Bentinck – Seventeenth Regulation of 1829: ✔️ Correct

    Lord William Bentinck passed Regulation XVII (1829) which abolished Sati in British India.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Wellesley used the Subsidiary Alliance to annex or control several princely states like Hyderabad, Awadh, and Mysore.
  • Lord Hastings expanded British control over India through the Third Anglo-Maratha War and suppression of the Pindaris.
  • Lord Bentinck was also known for social reforms, especially the suppression of Sati and Thuggee.

question:
When was Peshwai abolished?

U.P.P.C.S. (Mains) 2015
solution:
• The Peshwai (Prime Ministership of the Maratha Empire) was abolished in 1818 following the defeat of the Marathas in the Third Anglo-Maratha War (1817–1818).
  • The last Peshwa, Baji Rao II, was defeated by the British and exiled to Bithoor near Kanpur.
  • With his defeat, the British East India Company ended the Peshwa's authority, effectively dissolving the Maratha Confederacy’s central leadership.
  • This marked the final blow to Maratha political power, bringing most of India under British control.
  • The territories under the Peshwa were annexed and included in British dominions.

Additional Information:

  • The Third Anglo-Maratha War was led by Lord Hastings on behalf of the British.
  • After 1818, a puppet Maratha kingdom was allowed to remain in Satara, which was later annexed under the Doctrine of Lapse in 1848.

question:
Who among the following negotiated the Subordination Treaty of 1817-18 with the native princely states of Rajputana?

R.A.S./R.T.S. (Pre) 2018
solution:
• The Subordination Treaties of 1817–18 were part of the British policy to bring the Rajputana princely states under indirect British control after the downfall of the Marathas.
  • These treaties were negotiated under the Subsidiary Alliance system, where Indian rulers accepted British suzerainty in return for protection.
  • Charles Metcalfe, a senior British administrator under Lord Hastings, played a key role in negotiating these treaties with the Rajput states.
  • Through these agreements, states like Jaipur, Jodhpur, Udaipur, Bikaner, and Kota accepted British supremacy.
  • The goal was to prevent these states from allying with the Marathas or Pindaris and to establish British dominance in Rajputana without direct annexation.

Additional Information:

  • David Ochterlony was involved in the consolidation of British control in areas like Delhi and the Punjab hill states, but not specifically Rajputana.
  • Arthur Wellesley was active in South India and during earlier Subsidiary Alliance formations (e.g., with Hyderabad).
  • John George is not prominently associated with these 1817–18 Rajputana treaties.

question:
Which of the following is not correctly matched?

U.P.P.C.S. (Mains) 2014
option_1: Lord Cornwallis – Permanent Settlement
option_2: Lord Wellesley – Subsidiary Treaty System
option_3: Sir John Shore – Anglo-Nepal War
option_4: Lord Hastings – Third Anglo-Maratha War
solution:
• (a) Lord Cornwallis – Permanent Settlement: ✔️ Correct

    Introduced in 1793, the Permanent Settlement fixed land revenue with zamindars in Bengal under Lord Cornwallis.

  • (b) Lord Wellesley – Subsidiary Treaty System: ✔️ Correct

    Lord Wellesley aggressively expanded British influence through the Subsidiary Alliance System, forcing Indian states into British protection.

  • (c) Sir John Shore – Anglo-Nepal War: ❌ Incorrect

    The Anglo-Nepal War (1814–1816) was fought during the tenure of Lord Hastings, not Sir John Shore.

    Sir John Shore (Governor-General from 1793–1798) is known for his policy of non-intervention, not for military campaigns.

  • (d) Lord Hastings – Third Anglo-Maratha War: ✔️ Correct

    The Third Anglo-Maratha War (1817–1818) occurred during Lord Hastings' tenure, leading to the final collapse of the Maratha Empire.

Additional Information:

  • The Anglo-Nepal War ended with the Treaty of Sugauli (1816), reducing Nepal's territory and influence.
  • Lord Hastings also initiated the suppression of Pindaris along with the Marathas.

question:
Which one of the following is correctly matched?

U.P.P.C.S. (Mains) 2013
option_1: Lord Ellenborough : Annexation of Awadh
option_2: Lord Dalhousie : Annexation of Sindh
option_3: Lord Wellesley : Fourth Anglo-Mysore War
option_4: Sir John Shore : Third Anglo-Maratha War
solution:
• (a) Lord Ellenborough – Annexation of Awadh: ❌ Incorrect

    The Annexation of Awadh occurred in 1856 under Lord Dalhousie, not Ellenborough.

    Ellenborough is associated more with the return of the gates of Somnath and the First Afghan War withdrawal.

  • (b) Lord Dalhousie – Annexation of Sindh: ❌ Incorrect

    Sindh was annexed in 1843 under Sir Charles Napier, during the time of Lord Ellenborough, not Dalhousie.

  • (c) Lord Wellesley – Fourth Anglo-Mysore War: ✔️ Correct

    The Fourth Anglo-Mysore War (1799) was fought under Lord Wellesley’s tenure.

    This war led to the defeat and death of Tipu Sultan, and the end of Mysore's independent rule.

  • (d) Sir John Shore – Third Anglo-Maratha War: ❌ Incorrect

    The Third Anglo-Maratha War (1817–1818) took place during Lord Hastings’ tenure.

    Sir John Shore (1793–1798) is known for his non-interventionist approach.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Wellesley was known for his expansionist policy and Subsidiary Alliance system.
  • Tipu Sultan’s defeat led to significant British control in southern India.

question:
Which of the following pairs is not correctly matched?

U.P. Lower Sub. (Pre) 2013
option_1: Lord Dalhousie - Annexation of Oudh
option_2: Lord Dufferin - Establishment of Indian National Congress
option_3: Lord William Bentinck - Passing of Charter Act, 1833
option_4: Lord Lytton - Beginning of First Anglo-Afghan War
solution:
• (a) Lord Dalhousie – Annexation of Oudh: ✔️ Correct

    Oudh (Awadh) was annexed in 1856 by Lord Dalhousie citing "misgovernance" under the Doctrine of Lapse (though technically not a lapse case, it was annexed on administrative grounds).

  • (b) Lord Dufferin – Establishment of Indian National Congress: ✔️ Correct

    The Indian National Congress was founded in 1885, during the tenure of Lord Dufferin (Viceroy from 1884–1888). He initially viewed it as a “safety valve” for Indian political expression.

  • (c) Lord William Bentinck – Passing of Charter Act, 1833: ✔️ Correct

    The Charter Act of 1833, which centralized legislative powers and ended the commercial functions of the East India Company, was passed during Lord William Bentinck's tenure (Governor-General from 1828 to 1835).

  • (d) Lord Lytton – Beginning of First Anglo-Afghan War: ❌ Incorrect

    The First Anglo-Afghan War began in 1839 during the tenure of Lord Auckland, not Lord Lytton.

    Lord Lytton was involved in the Second Anglo-Afghan War (1878–1880).

Additional Information:

  • Lord Auckland initiated the first Anglo-Afghan War to install Shah Shuja on the throne of Kabul.
  • Lord Lytton also held the Delhi Durbar of 1877, where Queen Victoria was proclaimed Empress of India.

question:
Which of the following is associated with the policy of 'tactful inaction’?

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1997
solution:
• The policy of "tactful inaction" (also known as "masterly inactivity") is most closely associated with Lord John Lawrence.
  • He served as the Viceroy of India from 1864 to 1869 and was known for his non-interventionist foreign policy, especially toward Afghanistan.
  • During his tenure, instead of engaging in unnecessary wars or forward policies in Central Asia, he chose to maintain peace and stability by avoiding entanglement in Afghan affairs.
  • This policy was a strategic diplomatic approach based on caution and patience, rather than aggression.

Additional Information:

  • The term "masterly inactivity" was praised for saving resources and avoiding risky military campaigns.
  • In contrast, later Viceroys like Lord Lytton adopted a more aggressive stance, leading to the Second Anglo-Afghan War.

question:
Who started 'Financial Decentralization' in India?

Uttarakhand P.C.S. (Pre) 2021
solution:
• Lord Mayo is credited with initiating the process of financial decentralization in India.
  • In 1870, he introduced a system under which provincial governments were granted fixed shares of revenue and assigned specific expenditure responsibilities.
  • This move was intended to promote administrative efficiency by delegating powers and encouraging local responsibility.
  • It was a significant step toward modern fiscal federalism in India.
  • Mayo's reforms laid the foundation for later financial devolution policies adopted by successive administrations.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Ripon is known for local self-government reforms (1882), but not financial decentralization.
  • Charles Metcalfe is associated with freedom of the press.
  • Lord Dalhousie is remembered for the Doctrine of Lapse and railway/telegraph reforms.

question:
The first census in India was conducted during the British rule in-

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 2000

U.P. Lower Sub. (Spl.) (Pre) 2004
option_1: During Lord Dufferin's tenure
option_2: During Lord Lytton's tenure
option_3: During Lord Mayo's tenure
option_4: During Lord Ripon's tenure
solution:
• The first census in India was conducted in 1872 during the tenure of Lord Mayo.
  • Although this census was not synchronous (not conducted on the same date throughout the country), it was the first organized attempt to gather demographic data.
  • It laid the foundation for the decennial census system in India.
  • The first synchronous (simultaneous) census was conducted in 1881 during Lord Ripon's tenure.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Mayo also introduced financial decentralization in 1870.
  • Lord Ripon is known for local self-government reforms.
  • Lord Lytton’s tenure saw the Vernacular Press Act and Second Anglo-Afghan War.
  • Lord Dufferin was associated with the Indian National Congress formation (1885).

question:
Who was the person who conducted the first population census in India?

Uttarakhand P.C.S. (Mains) 2006
solution:
• The first population census in India was conducted in 1872 during the tenure of Lord Mayo.
  • The person responsible for organizing and conducting this census was W.C. Plowden, who was then the Census Commissioner of India.
  • Though Lord Mayo was the Governor-General who initiated the process, the actual fieldwork was done under the supervision of Plowden.
  • This 1872 census was not synchronous, but it marked the first nationwide demographic survey.

Additional Information:

  • The first synchronous and complete census took place in 1881, under Lord Ripon.
  • Later censuses were held every 10 years, continuing into modern India.
  • Lord Mayo is thus credited with starting the process of census in India.

question:
Which Viceroy was murdered by a convicted criminal in the Andaman Nicobar Islands (while he was on a tour)?

U.P.P.C.S. (Pre) 2004

U.P.R.O./A.R.O. (Mains) 2013
solution:
• Lord Mayo, the Viceroy of India, was assassinated on 8 February 1872.
  • He was murdered by Sher Ali, a convicted Pathan prisoner, at the Port Blair prison in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands.
  • Lord Mayo was on an official inspection tour of the penal settlement when the attack took place.
  • This was the only instance in British India where a serving Viceroy was assassinated.
  • The incident deeply shocked the British administration and led to increased security measures.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Curzon is known for the Partition of Bengal (1905).
  • Lord Ripon introduced local self-government reforms in 1882.
  • Lord Minto is remembered for the Morley-Minto Reforms of 1909.

question:
Which Viceroy was assassinated during his tenure?

Uttarakhand P.C.S. (Pre) 2010
solution:
• Lord Mayo was the only Viceroy of India to be assassinated during his tenure.
  • He was killed on 8 February 1872 by Sher Ali, a convicted prisoner, at the Port Blair prison in the Andaman and Nicobar Islands.
  • Lord Mayo was on an official inspection of the penal settlement when the attack took place.
  • His assassination shocked the British authorities and prompted tighter security protocols.
  • The incident remains unparalleled in the history of British India.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Curzon is known for the 1905 Partition of Bengal.
  • Lord Ripon promoted local self-government in India.
  • Lord Wellesley is associated with the Subsidiary Alliance system.

question:
About Lord Mayo's resolution of 1870, which of the following statements are correct?

It was the first step to divide central and provincial finances.

2. Provincial governments were given the right to administer some services.

3. It attempted to rectify the existing inequality.

4. It focused on the real needs of the provinces.

Select the correct answer using the code given below.

69th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2023
solution:
• Statement 1 – Correct: Lord Mayo's Resolution of 1870 was the first major attempt at financial decentralization in British India, introducing the division of finances between the centre and provinces.
  • Statement 2 – Correct: Under this resolution, provincial governments were granted administrative control over certain areas such as public works, police, education, and medical services.
  • Statement 3 – Correct: The resolution aimed to address the imbalance and inequality between the central authority and provincial governments by giving them greater responsibility and autonomy.
  • Statement 4 – Correct: By empowering provinces to manage specific sectors, the resolution tried to align administration with local needs and realities, thus making governance more practical and region-specific.

Hence, all four statements are correct.

Additional Information:

  • The resolution is seen as the foundation of fiscal federalism in India.
  • It marked a shift from centralized to decentralized administration, which was further expanded by later Viceroys like Lord Ripon.

question:
The Governor General who followed an enthusiastic 'Forward' policy towards Afghanistan was-

I.A.S. (Pre) 1999
solution:
• The 'Forward Policy' was an aggressive strategy adopted by British India to expand influence in frontier regions, particularly Afghanistan.
  • Lord Lytton (Viceroy of India: 1876–1880) is best known for pursuing this assertive policy toward Afghanistan.
  • His forward approach led to the Second Anglo-Afghan War (1878–1880).
  • The aim was to counter Russian influence in Afghanistan and establish a pro-British ruler in Kabul.
  • Lytton's tenure is marked by this militant foreign policy, contrasting with later ‘masterly inactivity’ approaches.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Minto followed a more defensive frontier policy.
  • Lord Dufferin focused on Burma affairs and consolidation.
  • "Alligan" seems to be a typographical error or misprint, not an actual Governor General.

question:
Which Viceroy had adopted aggressive policy towards Afghanistan?

65th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2019
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• Lord Lytton (Viceroy of India: 1876–1880) adopted an aggressive ‘Forward Policy’ toward Afghanistan.
  • His main aim was to counter Russian influence in the region during the Great Game between Britain and Russia.
  • Under this policy, he sent a British mission to Kabul, and when it was denied entry, it led to the Second Anglo-Afghan War (1878–1880).
  • The war was intended to establish a pro-British ruler in Afghanistan and assert British dominance over the frontier.
  • This policy marked a clear departure from the earlier non-interventionist (masterly inactivity) stance.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Mayo focused on internal reforms and financial decentralization, not foreign aggression.
  • Lord Dufferin was more involved in Burma and consolidation, not Afghanistan.
  • Lord Canning dealt with the aftermath of the 1857 revolt and was largely focused on internal stability.

question:
Lord Lytton is not related to which of the following?

69th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2023
solution:
• Strachey Commission (Famine Commission) – Related: Formed in 1878 under Lord Lytton to investigate the famine of 1876–78 and recommend preventive measures.
  • Arms Act (1878) – Related: Passed during Lord Lytton’s tenure, it restricted Indians from possessing arms without a license, while Europeans were exempt.
  • Vernacular Press Act (1878) – Related: Introduced by Lord Lytton to curb the freedom of the Indian-language press, especially vernacular newspapers critical of British rule.
  • Ilbert Bill (1883) – Not Related: This was introduced under Lord Ripon, not Lytton, and aimed to allow Indian judges to try British offenders in criminal cases, which led to huge protests from the British community.

Thus, Ilbert Bill is not related to Lord Lytton.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Lytton also presided over the Delhi Durbar of 1877, proclaiming Queen Victoria as the Empress of India.
  • His policies were criticized for being authoritarian and repressive during famine and for curbing civil liberties.

question:
Who remained the Viceroy of India for the longest period?

U.P. P.C.S. (Mains) 2009
solution:
• Lord Curzon served as the Viceroy of India from 1899 to 1905, making his tenure the longest continuous viceroyalty in British India (a full 6 years).
  • He implemented major administrative, educational, and territorial reforms.
  • His notable actions include the Partition of Bengal in 1905, the establishment of the Archaeological Survey of India as a formal institution, and improvements in irrigation and police systems.
  • His policies, especially the partition, led to significant nationalist opposition and movements like Swadeshi.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Dufferin (1884–1888) – 4 years.
  • Lord Hardinge (1910–1916) – 6 years, but slightly shorter than Curzon’s.
  • Lord Mayo (1869–1872) – Assassinated during his term, served less than 4 years.

question:
Local self-governing bodies in India were empowered in 1882 AD-

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1994
solution:
• In 1882, Lord Ripon, then Viceroy of India, introduced resolutions on local self-government.
  • These reforms are regarded as the foundation of democratic decentralization in India.
  • The aim was to involve Indians in local administration through municipal boards and district boards.
  • Lord Ripon’s efforts earned him the title "Father of Local Self-Government in India."
  • These bodies were given powers related to education, sanitation, public health, and infrastructure at the local level.

Additional Information:

  • George Barlow acted as Governor-General (1805–1807) with no major decentralization policy.
  • Lord Curzon is associated with Partition of Bengal (1905).
  • Lord Lytton was known for repressive measures like the Vernacular Press Act and Arms Act, not decentralization.

question:
Who encouraged local self-rule in India?

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1996

Uttarakhand P.C.S. (Mains) 2002

U.P.P.C.S. (Pre) 2010
solution:
• Lord Ripon (Viceroy of India: 1880–1884) is best known for his promotion of local self-rule in India.
  • In 1882, he issued a resolution that laid the foundation of local self-government, allowing Indians to participate in municipal boards and district councils.
  • His efforts marked a shift from centralized control to democratic decentralization at the local level.
  • Due to his contributions, Lord Ripon is often called the "Father of Local Self-Government in India."

Additional Information:

  • Lord Mayo introduced financial decentralization in 1870, not self-rule.
  • Lord Lytton is associated with repressive laws like the Vernacular Press Act.
  • Lord Canning was the first Viceroy after 1857 and focused on administrative reconstruction.

question:
What was the Ilbert Bill controversy related to?

I.A.S. (Pre) 2013
option_1: Imposition of certain restrictions on the carrying of arms by Indians
option_2: Imposition of a ban on the publication of newspapers and magazines in Indian languages
option_3: Removal of disqualifications imposed on Indian judges to try cases of Europeans
option_4: Removal of duty imposed on imported cotton cloth
solution:
• The Ilbert Bill Controversy arose in 1883 during the tenure of Lord Ripon, who sought to pass a bill drafted by Sir Courtenay Ilbert.
  • The bill proposed to remove racial disqualifications by allowing Indian judges and magistrates to try European British subjects in criminal cases.
  • This move was seen by the British community in India as a threat to their racial superiority, and it triggered massive protests, especially from Europeans.
  • Under pressure, the bill was modified, allowing Europeans to opt for jury trials where at least half the jurors were European.
  • The controversy highlighted the racial divide and exposed British reluctance to accept judicial equality.

Additional Information:

  • (a) refers to the Arms Act (1878) under Lord Lytton.
  • (b) refers to the Vernacular Press Act (1878).
  • (d) relates to economic policies, not Ilbert Bill.

question:
In the context of colonial rule in India, the objective of the 'Ilbert Bill' passed in 1883 AD was-

I.A.S. (Pre) 2003
option_1: Putting Indians and Europeans on equal footing as far as the criminal jurisdiction of the courts was concerned.
option_2: Strictly restricting the freedom of the native press; as it was seen as hostile to the colonial rulers.
option_3: Holding the civil service examinations in India to encourage native Indians to appear for them.
option_4: Amending the Arms Act to allow native Indians to bear arms.
solution:
• The Ilbert Bill, introduced in 1883 by Lord Ripon's government, aimed to place Indian and European subjects on an equal footing with respect to criminal jurisdiction.
  • The bill proposed that Indian judges and magistrates be empowered to try British/European subjects in criminal cases, which was previously restricted.
  • This effort was part of Lord Ripon's liberal and reformist agenda to promote equality in judicial administration.
  • The bill faced strong opposition from the European community in India, leading to widespread protests and ultimately a compromised version of the bill was passed.
  • Despite the rollback, the Ilbert Bill remains a symbol of the Indian demand for judicial equality and racial justice.

Additional Information:

  • (b) refers to the Vernacular Press Act (1878) under Lord Lytton.
  • (c) relates to the introduction of ICS exams in India (post-1854), but not Ilbert Bill.
  • (d) refers to the Arms Act (1878) which restricted Indians from bearing arms.

question:
During whose tenure the first Factory Act was adopted restricting the working hours of women and children and authorising the local government to make necessary regulations?

I.A.S. (Pre) 2007
solution:
• The first Factory Act in India was enacted in 1881 during the tenure of Lord Ripon (Viceroy from 1880–1884).
  • This act was the first legislative step to regulate labor conditions, especially concerning women and children in factories.
  • It restricted the working hours of children, prohibited the employment of children below 7 years, and limited working hours to 9 hours per day for those between 7–12 years.
  • It also empowered the local governments to make necessary rules and to appoint inspectors for implementation.
  • The act was a foundation for future labor reforms in India.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Lytton is known for the Vernacular Press Act and Arms Act (1878), not labor reforms.
  • Lord Bentinck is famous for abolishing Sati (1829).
  • Lord Canning was the first Viceroy of India after the 1857 revolt and focused on post-rebellion administration.

question:
Consider the following statements-

The Factory Act, 1881 was passed with a view to fixing wages of industrial workers and to allow workers to form trade unions.

2. N.M. Lokhande was a pioneer in organising the labour movement in British India.

Which of the above statements is/are correct?

I.A.S. (Pre.) Exam, 2017
solution:
• Statement 1 – Incorrect: The Factory Act of 1881 did not deal with fixing wages or allowing trade unions.

    It primarily aimed at regulating working conditions, especially for children, such as:

    • Prohibiting employment of children under 7 years
    • Limiting working hours for children between 7–12 years
    • Mandating basic health and safety conditions
  • Statement 2 – Correct: Narayan Meghaji Lokhande is considered the pioneer of the labour movement in British India.
    • He founded Bombay Mill Hands Association in 1890, the first organized labour association in India.
    • He fought for better working hours, weekly holidays, and general welfare of industrial workers.

Thus, only statement 2 is correct.

Additional Information:

  • The Trade Unions Act legalizing union formation came much later in 1926.
  • The 1881 Act was passed during Lord Ripon's tenure and marked the beginning of labor legislation in India.

question:
Who among the following is considered the father of 'local self-government' in India?

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 2015
solution:
• Lord Ripon is known as the "Father of Local Self-Government" in India.
  • In 1882, he introduced a resolution that laid the foundation for local self-governance in rural and urban areas.
  • His resolution emphasized decentralization of power and popular participation in administration through local bodies.
  • Under his policy, municipal committees and local boards were given more powers and the majority of their members were to be elected, not nominated.
  • This marked the beginning of representative local institutions in India.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Dalhousie is known for the Doctrine of Lapse and Railway beginnings.
  • Lord Canning was the last Governor-General and the first Viceroy of India.
  • Lord Curzon is known for the Partition of Bengal (1905) and establishing the Archaeological Survey of India.

question:
Which of the following pairs is not correctly matched?

R.O./A.R.O. (Pre.) 2017
option_1: Local self-government - Lord Lytton
option_2: Subsidiary Treaty - Lord Wellesley
option_3: States - Abduction Policy - Lord Dalhousie

  • Local self-government was introduced by Lord Ripon in 1882, not Lord Lytton.
  • Lord Lytton (1876–1880) is known for the Vernacular Press Act (1878) and the First Delhi Durbar (1877), not for local self-governance reforms.

Correctly Matched Pairs:

  • Subsidiary Treaty – Lord Wellesley: Introduced the Subsidiary Alliance system to expand British control.
  • States – Abduction Policy – Lord Dalhousie: Known for the Doctrine of Lapse, through which many Indian states were annexed.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Ripon’s 1882 resolution focused on decentralization and democratic participation in local governance.
  • The Doctrine of Lapse allowed annexation if a ruler died without a natural male heir.

question:
Which of the following pair (Governor General and event) is correctly matched?

Chhattisgarh P.C.S. (Pre) 2008
option_3: Lord Ellenborough-Annexation of Sindh
option_4: Lord Dalhousie-First Afghan War
solution:
Let’s verify each option:

  • (a) Lord Cornwallis – Regulating Act → Incorrect

    The Regulating Act of 1773 was passed during the time of Warren Hastings, not Lord Cornwallis.

    Lord Cornwallis is associated with the Permanent Settlement of Bengal (1793).

  • (b) Lord Wellesley – Permanent Settlement → Incorrect

    The Permanent Settlement was introduced by Lord Cornwallis, not Wellesley.

    Wellesley is known for the Subsidiary Alliance system.

  • (c) Lord Ellenborough – Annexation of Sindh → Correct

    Sindh was annexed by the British in 1843 during the tenure of Lord Ellenborough after the Battle of Miani.

  • (d) Lord Dalhousie – First Afghan War → Incorrect

    The First Anglo-Afghan War (1839–42) occurred during the time of Lord Auckland, not Dalhousie.

    Dalhousie is known for Doctrine of Lapse, Railway development, and Postal reforms.

question:
In whose period was the Archaeological Survey of India established?

U.P. Lower (Pre) 2009
solution:
• The Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), as a formal organization, was reorganized and institutionalized during the time of Lord Curzon.
  • Though initial efforts for archaeological work in India began earlier (under people like Alexander Cunningham in the 19th century), it was Lord Curzon (1899–1905) who gave strong administrative support and made archaeology a systematic government effort.
  • He passed the Ancient Monuments Preservation Act, 1904, which laid the legal foundation for protecting historical monuments in India.
  • Under his leadership, ASI became a properly structured department, and major conservation projects began.

Additional Information:

  • Warren Hastings encouraged oriental studies but not archaeology as a formal discipline.
  • Lord Wellesley focused on military and administrative reforms.
  • Lord William Bentinck is known for social reforms like the abolition of Sati, not archaeological development.

Answer: (c) Lord Curzon

question:
The Archaeological Survey of India was established in-

U.P.P.C.S. (Mains) 2010
option_1: During the period of Lord Curzon
option_2: During the period of Lord Wellesley
option_3: During the period of Lord William Bentinck
option_4: During the period of Warren Hastings
solution:
• While initial archaeological activities in India began earlier (notably under Warren Hastings and Lord William Bentinck), the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) was formally established in 1861 by Alexander Cunningham, during the time of Lord Canning, not Lord Curzon.
  • However, in the context of institutional development and legal recognition, it was Lord Curzon (1899–1905) who gave major administrative support to ASI.
  • Lord Curzon enacted the Ancient Monuments Preservation Act in 1904, which provided a legal framework for protecting India’s heritage.
  • Therefore, while ASI was founded earlier, its formal recognition, organization, and expansion as a key institution happened under Lord Curzon.

Hence, as per the spirit of the question and official answer key, the correct answer is:

(a) During the period of Lord Curzon

question:
Who among the following established the 'Archaeological Survey Department’?

Chhattisgarh P.S.C. (Pre) 2018
solution:
• The Archaeological Survey Department, now known as the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), was initially established in 1861 by Alexander Cunningham under Lord Canning.
  • However, in many state exams like Chhattisgarh PSC, the phrase "established the Archaeological Survey Department" often refers to the reorganization and formal strengthening of the department.
  • In this sense, Lord Curzon (1899–1905) is credited with:
    • Reviving and restructuring the ASI
    • Passing the Ancient Monuments Preservation Act, 1904
    • Expanding the department’s functions and making heritage conservation a state responsibility
  • Hence, though not the founder, Lord Curzon played the most significant role in institutionalizing the Archaeological Survey Department.

Answer: (a) Lord Curzon

question:
During the tenure of which Governor General was the Ancient Monuments Preservation Act passed?

U.P. P.C.S. (Mains) 2005

U.P.U.D.A/L.D.A. (Spl.) (Mains) 2010
solution:
• The Ancient Monuments Preservation Act was passed in the year 1904.
  • This act was a landmark step in the protection and conservation of India's historical monuments.
  • It empowered the government to declare monuments as protected, regulate excavation activities, and prevent their misuse or damage.
  • This act was enacted during the tenure of Lord Curzon, who served as the Governor-General and Viceroy of India from 1899 to 1905.
  • Lord Curzon is especially known for his passion for archaeology and for reviving and reorganizing the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI).

Answer: (c) Lord Curzon

question:
Who compared Curzon's administration in India with that of Aurangzeb?

U.P. P.C.S. (Mains) 2012
solution:
• The comparison of Lord Curzon’s administration with that of Aurangzeb was made by Gopal Krishna Gokhale.
  • He criticized Curzon’s authoritarian and centralizing policies, particularly after the Partition of Bengal in 1905, which sparked intense national protest.
  • Gokhale remarked that Curzon’s rule was rigid, autocratic, and unsympathetic to Indian opinion—similar to the unpopular and oppressive policies of Aurangzeb.
  • The comparison highlighted how Curzon’s actions alienated Indians and fueled the growth of Indian nationalism.

Answer: (b) G.K. Gokhale

question:
Who founded the Imperial Cadet Copers?

63rd B.P.S.C. (Pre) Exam. 2017
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• The Imperial Cadet Corps (ICC) was founded by Lord Curzon in 1901.
  • It was established with the aim of training sons of Indian princes and nobles for military service in the British Indian Army.
  • The idea was to integrate the Indian aristocracy into the British military structure and ensure their loyalty to the colonial administration.
  • However, the ICC never became a fully integrated military force and was largely ceremonial in nature.
  • It reflected Curzon’s policy of patronizing the princely class while maintaining strong imperial control.

Answer: (b) Lord Curzon

question:
Consider the following Viceroys during the British Empire in India-

Lord Curzon

3. Lord Chelmsford

2. Lord Hardinge

4. Lord Irwin

The correct chronological order of the tenures of the above is-

I.A.S. (Pre) 2004
solution:
Let’s arrange the Viceroys in correct chronological order based on their tenure:

  1. Lord Curzon – 1899 to 1905

    Known for Partition of Bengal (1905), Ancient Monuments Act, Imperial Cadet Corps, and promotion of education and archaeology.

  2. Lord Hardinge – 1910 to 1916

    Oversaw the Delhi Durbar of 1911, transfer of capital from Calcutta to Delhi, and the start of WWI.

  3. Lord Chelmsford – 1916 to 1921

    Known for the Montagu-Chelmsford Reforms (1919) and Jallianwala Bagh massacre (1919).

  4. Lord Irwin – 1926 to 1931

    Associated with the Simon Commission protests, Civil Disobedience Movement, and the Gandhi-Irwin Pact (1931).

  • Lord Curzon (1st)
  • Lord Hardinge (2nd)
  • Lord Chelmsford (3rd)
  • Lord Irwin (4th)

So, the correct sequence is:

1 – 2 – 3 – 4

Answer: (a) 1-2-3-4

question:
With reference to Civil Administration 1905, which of the statements is/are correct?

Lord Curzon decided to reorganise the provincial boundaries.

2. A new province called East Bengal and Assam was created.

Select the correct answer from the codes given below –

U.P.P.C.S. (Pre) 2019
solution:
• Statement 1 is correct: In 1905, Lord Curzon undertook the reorganization of provincial boundaries in British India. This was part of his administrative reform to improve efficiency but had underlying political motives to divide Bengal on communal lines.
  • Statement 2 is correct: The Partition of Bengal in 1905 led to the creation of a new province named East Bengal and Assam, with Dacca (Dhaka) as its capital. The remaining western part continued as the Bengal province with Calcutta as its capital.

Additional Information:

  • The partition was officially implemented on 16 October 1905.
  • It sparked massive protests, especially from the Indian National Congress and Bengali nationalists, leading to the Swadeshi Movement.
  • The partition was eventually annulled in 1911 due to strong opposition.
  • This was seen as a classic example of ‘Divide and Rule’ policy.

question:
Which of the statements is/are correct with reference to Lord Curzon?

Establishing the British Empire on a granite rock.

2. Proclamation of the Calcutta Corporation Act.

Select the correct answer using the code given below:

U.P. R.O./A.R.O. (Pre) 2023

Code :
solution:
• Statement 1 is correct: Lord Curzon famously stated that his goal was to establish the British Empire on a granite rock, symbolizing strong and unshakeable British rule in India. This was reflective of his authoritarian and centralizing administrative style.
  • Statement 2 is correct: Lord Curzon was responsible for the Calcutta Corporation Act of 1899, which curtailed the powers of Indian representatives in the Calcutta Municipal Corporation and increased British control. This was part of his broader policy to reinforce imperial authority.

Additional Information:

  • Curzon served as Viceroy of India from 1899 to 1905.
  • He introduced several reforms in education, police, and administration, but was also criticized for centralizing power and excluding Indians.
  • He also initiated the Partition of Bengal in 1905, which faced massive opposition and was later reversed in 1911.

question:
The strategy of 'divide and rule' was adopted by-

U.P.R.O./A.R.O. (Pre) 2014
solution:
• Lord Curzon (Viceroy 1899–1905) is widely known for applying the ‘Divide and Rule’ strategy, especially through the Partition of Bengal in 1905. This move separated Hindus and Muslims geographically, sowing communal discord under the guise of administrative convenience.
  • Lord Minto (Viceroy 1905–1910) institutionalized this divide by introducing Separate Electorates for Muslims through the Indian Councils Act of 1909 (Morley-Minto Reforms). This formally embedded communal representation in politics.

Thus, both Lord Curzon and Lord Minto are associated with the 'Divide and Rule' strategy.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Dalhousie focused more on annexation policies like the Doctrine of Lapse, not divide-and-rule.
  • Lord Wellesley is known for the Subsidiary Alliance, not communal strategies.

question:
"I am convinced that the Congress is heading towards its destruction and it would be my earnest desire, while in India, to be instrumental in its peaceful demise." Who wrote this?

B.P.C.S. (Pre) 2016
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• The statement "I am convinced that the Congress is heading towards its destruction and it would be my earnest desire, while in India, to be instrumental in its peaceful demise" was made by Lord Curzon.
  • He viewed the Indian National Congress as a threat to British authority and aimed to suppress its influence through administrative and political measures, including the Partition of Bengal (1905).
  • His policies and attitude intensified nationalist sentiment and directly contributed to the rise of the Swadeshi Movement.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Curzon served as the Viceroy of India from 1899 to 1905.
  • He also introduced university reforms, created the Imperial Cadet Corps, and preserved archaeological heritage — but his legacy remains controversial due to his divisive policies.
  • His quote reflects the colonial mindset that sought to undermine the early nationalist movements in India.

question:
Which of the following Governor Generals first used the system of 'separate electorate' to win over the Muslims and turn them against the Congress?

M.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1997
solution:
• The system of ‘separate electorate’ was first introduced under Lord Minto, through the Indian Councils Act of 1909, also known as the Morley-Minto Reforms.
  • This system allowed Muslims to elect their own representatives separately, a clear attempt to create political divisions and undermine the unity of the Indian national movement, especially the Congress.
  • Lord Minto is thus known as the "Father of Communal Electorates" in India.

Additional Information:

  • Lord Curzon (Viceroy 1899–1905) implemented the Partition of Bengal to divide Hindus and Muslims geographically but did not introduce the separate electorate system.
  • Lord Dufferin (1884–1888) witnessed the birth of the Congress but did not implement communal electorates.
  • Lord Hardinge (1910–1916) oversaw the annulment of Bengal's partition and shifted the capital from Calcutta to Delhi.

question:
Who among the following was the only Jewish Viceroy of India?

U.P.R.O./A.R.O. (Mains) 2014
solution:
• The only Jewish Viceroy of India was Lord Reading.
  • His full name was Rufus Isaacs, 1st Marquess of Reading, and he served as the Viceroy and Governor-General of India from 1921 to 1926.
  • He was the first person of Jewish origin to hold this high post in British India.

Additional Information:

  • During his tenure, India witnessed:
    • The Non-Cooperation Movement (1920–22) and its aftermath.
    • The arrest of Mahatma Gandhi in 1922.
    • The Khilafat Movement and communal tensions.
  • Lord Reading also served as Chief Justice of England before becoming Viceroy.

solution:

    Lord William Bentinck, Governor-General (1828–1835), actively worked to suppress the Thuggee cult with the help of officers like Captain Sleeman.

  • (b) Ilbert Bill – Ripon: ✅Correctly matched

    The Ilbert Bill (1883) was introduced during Lord Ripon’s tenure. It aimed to allow Indian judges to try European British subjects, but faced stiff resistance.

question:
The transfer of the capital of British India from Calcutta to Delhi was implemented during whose period?

U.P. U.D.A./L.D.A. (Pre) 2006
solution:
• The capital of British India was transferred from Calcutta to Delhi in 1911, during the Delhi Durbar held in honor of King George V.
  • This historic event took place during the viceroyalty of Lord Hardinge (1910–1916).
  • The actual administrative shift took place after the announcement, and New Delhi was inaugurated as the new capital in 1931, but the decision and implementation began under Lord Hardinge.

Additional Information:

  • The announcement was made on 12 December 1911.
  • One major reason for the shift was that Delhi was more centrally located and had symbolic significance as a former seat of many Indian empires.
  • The decision also coincided with the annulment of the Partition of Bengal (1905).
